The blue-sky bull case for CZR was that the legacy business would stabilize at margins still above pre-pandemic levels, while the digital business grew into a multi-billion-dollar valuation. Both sides of that case took a hit.

Yet there doesn't seem to be much urgency from Reeg and management, even with the stock at a five-year low. Instead, there is a lot of discussion about what is going on outside the business. Indeed, toward the beginning of Reeg's prepared remarks, the CEO noted that the quarter took a hit of "a little over $10 million of one-time items that benefited us last year and didn't repeat". That seems to add some context to the profit decline in the quarter.

The problem is that if you go back a year, Reeg opened his prepared remarks by noting that in Q3 2024 there were $10 million in one-time expenses that weren't added back to Adjusted EBITDA. This is becoming a constant pattern: earnings are going in the wrong direction, the stock has been halved in twelve months, and yet per Reeg, everything is fine. That in turn raises serious doubts about Reeg's insistence that digital targets are on track. So does the fact that three quarters ago, Reeg was musing about reaching $1 billion in free cash flow this year; the figure through three quarters is $350 million.

Given that Q3 suggests a business facing serious challenges both in brick-and-mortar and digital, confidence in management is paramount. And at this point, it's difficult to have that confidence. As I've written before, Reeg was instrumental in the hugely impressive roll-up that Eldorado executed over the last decade. But more recently, it's been a very different story: Caesars' stock is now down 48% since the beginning of 2019. (The S&P 500, including dividends, has tripled).

As with Q3, there are explanations for that underperformance and reasons to believe that the trend will eventually turn. But that's been the case for some time now, and the trend hasn't turned. It does seem like big changes may well be needed — but it's hard to bet on those changes happening when Caesars' management continues to act as if nothing is really wrong.

data.title: Curveballs: Opportunities For The U.S. Grid
data.description:
Flat Growth Has Led to Flat-Footedness: With electricity consumption flat for almost two decades, US load growth was stagnant from 2000 to 2020. In 2025, the public and private sectors have been scrambling to build out infrastructure and rein in retail prices as data center buildouts and electrification continue to drive consumption.

More Pain for Households: The mid-Atlantic region serves as a proxy for residential electricity prices. Its June 2025 capacity auction prices continued to hit all-time highs; 45% of total power costs were attributed to data centers, or $7.3B. With no relief in sight, retail electricity prices are expected to continue rising into at least 2026.

Projected Transmissions Expansion: Transmission is an underappreciated facet of the grid and has been underinvested in for almost 20 years. Projected expansion through 2040 - even in high-load parts of the grid - may not be enough to withstand projected demand, which should double by 2035.

Producer Prices Are Also Rising: Copper is a key input in transmission and distribution lines; supply chain issues - including imports - and rising costs will be a headwind to producer and retail prices.

Co-location Has Yet to Take Off: Co-locating power capacity and production at data centers has been floated as a popular solution but only accounts for 7% of US facilities. With a 4+ year backlog in gas turbines, co-located renewable power remains an alternative, though battery storage remains an outstanding problem.

Look to Texas for Innovation: Comparing Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Maryland (PJM) and the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT), Texas is poised to be a big winner of managing retail prices and renewable energy growth and innovation. The Texas grid has stabilized power prices during seasonal peak loads; it is also increasingly supported by solar and battery storage, and both are projected to grow through 2030.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.
